captions.text: Hi guys, we're still in Tokyo
and tonight we'll be having another Japanese delicacy: the very popular and much loved okonomiyaki.
Okonomiyaki is one of those dishes you sometimes prepare yourself in a restaurant
not always, sometimes they serve it pre-made
this is the real deal though.
So first thing you've got to mix it all nicely
this one is beef, kimchi...
the one she's having is called the 'seafood party'.
The main ingredient here is the cabbage,
and the egg holds it all together.
You pour some oil over the hot plate
and spread it all evenly.
You empty out our bowl,
You can mold it into this kind of glop
round-ish shaped glop
about an inch thick.
Attention, children!
Krzysiek is about to perform a difficult task of flipping okonomiyaki over.
Can we please have a zoom here?
This is okonomiyaki sauce, with a brush
that we use to spread it nicely.
Next step is to sprinkle some katsuobushi on it,
they are dried bonito fish flakes.
It's a familiar picture, those fish flakes
wavering on top of okonomiyaki.
Next, you sprinkle even more stuff on it, this time it's dried aonori seaweed.
And now the finishing touch, Japanese mayo
no need to go easy on it.
You want to make it into a lattice shape.
Let's say it's lattice, more or less.
And when it's ready, all that's left is cutting it into slices.
Our resident expert here demonstrates how to do it.
Alrighty, let's try it.
You can work it with your chopsticks a little.
There we go.
Now that was hot. I think I died a little bit.
Doesn't change the fact it's still good stuff.
The first one we had was seafood, that was very good, now we're having kimchi and pork.
The okonomiyaki flavour is very rich, very intricate.
You can tell there is a lot going on, all those ingredients mixed together
The sweet element is pretty strong,
but there's a sour side to it as well, thanks to cabbage, mostly.
A pretty nice combo, if you ask me.
This is monja - a different version of okonomiyaki that's specific to Tokyo.
I mixed it already.
The cooking technique is slightly different
because there's a bit more liquid, so first you have to
get the dry stuff out.
Onto the hot plate.
And you cut it up a little bit, so it's less of a pain to mix it later.
When you're done, you form a little
circle in the middle.
Some of the liquid that's left over is being poured in, not all of it though.
So that it doesn't overflow.
As soon as the little puddle in the middle starts to boil
you can mix it all up again.
And you mould it into a ring shape again, leaving some space for the leftover water.
Ok, let's finish this up.
Ok, now that it's all starting to come together nicely
you grab a bit - you can flip it over for a second,
put it on this special spatula thing
make sure you don't burn yourself again.
I really love this culture, and it's not only a Japanese thing,
but it's common in Asia, the culture of preparing the meal together from scratch,
and sharing it, like - sharing the same big bowl of food.
- You prepare it together, everything you order you get to share with all the others...
- Yeah.
- It's a cool thing. A little bit absurd, too
you remember that line from 'Lost in Translation'?
'What kind of place makes you cook your own food?'
But it's actually a lot of fun,
and working out all the ingredients and cooking is a bit of a challenge too.
So you pay for this experience as well.
And if you ask the waiter to do it for you, they'll do it.
To be honest.
Yeah, but that's the whole fun, isn't it? Doing it yourself.
- Yes, and it's not that expensive either...
How much did we pay? Something like 700-800 yen per portion.
which makes it...
Dunno.

- 7 dollars or so.
- Yeah sounds about right. Not a bad price.
It really fills you up.
- How about which one's better? Monja or okonomiyaki?

- Because they're quite different.
- Yeah...
I think I'm gonna vote okonomiyaki here, I feel like with monja...
...we didn't quite nail it just yet.
Like, really nail it.
Making okonomiyaki is easy-peasy, it can't go wrong.
Monja, on the other hand, is much harder.
Which might be the reason, uh, we still suck.
- But you know what? I still dig the flavour
the texture's a bit softer, flavour a bit less pancakey
a bit more... raw?
Which could be due to our poor technique.
But the flavour is completely different, that's for sure.
- Monja was very good, I liked it. I did.
It's just that okonomiyaki was better.
- Cool. So that was the new installment of our Japanese munchies extravaganza, straight from Tokyo.

- Bye for now!
- Laters.
keep up with our Japanese adventures on  youtube.com/wybuchajacebeczki

title: Japońska pizza - Okonomiyaki! [Japonia, Tokio] // Okonomiyaki & monja in Tokyo
